member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Extensibility.Editor.ITextDocumentSnapshot
member.summary: Provides read access to an immutable version of a document in the file system, in memory in this process, or remoted from the host Visual Studio.

remarks.para: represents a document at a point in time and does not change. Most IDE features will be invoked with an with the state of the document when the feature was invoked.

Some advanced scenarios may benefit from caching results computed against previous versions. To facilitate such caching, supports 'translating' positions and ranges on a document between versions using and , respectively.
is not directly mutable. Any changes must be requested via EditorExtensibility.EditAsync(Action<IEditBatch>, System.Threading.CancellationToken).

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Extensibility.Editor.TextExtensions.CopyToString(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Extensibility.Editor.TextRange)
member.summary: Copies the to a string.
member.returns: A non-null string.
member.remarks:
Copying text from a large range to a string is very expensive and should be avoided.
You can use and to represent substrings in a document without expending resources copying or allocating strings. Most APIs operate in terms of these primitives.
You can use the indexer syntax on , to read or compare character by character in a document without copying it to a string.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Extensibility.Editor.TextPosition
member.summary: An immutable text position in a particular version.

remarks.para: is one of three closely related concepts: - : Thick object representing a range of text in a . This type should be used in all code within the same process. - : A serializable representation of that can be sent between processes over RPC. This type should be used in most RPC contracts between processes. - : A serialiable representation of that can be sent between processes over RPC. As opposed to , it omits the and document version, making for a smaller serializable representation. This type should be used in RPC contracts that contain lots of position equivalents that need to reduce their payload size for performance. These RPC contracts will need to pass the document and version for the range to be rehydrated into by .

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Extensibility.Editor.TextPositionTrackingMode
member.summary: Represents tracking modes for s across versions of an .

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Extensibility.Editor.TextPositionTrackingMode.Positive
member.summary: With this setting, a position tracks toward the end of the document, so that an insertion at the current position pushes the position to the end of the inserted text. If a replacement contains the position, it will end up at the end of the replacement text.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Extensibility.Editor.TextPositionTrackingMode.Negative
member.summary: With this setting, a position tracks toward the beginning of the document, so that an insertion at the current position leaves the position unaffected. If a replacement contains the position, it will end up at the beginning of the replacement text.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Extensibility.Editor.TextRange
member.summary: An immutable text range in a particular version.

remarks.para: is one of four closely related concepts:

list.item: : Thick object representing a range of text in a . This type should be used in all code within the same process.
: A serializable representation of that can be sent between processes over RPC. This type should be used in most RPC contracts between processes.

: A serializable representation of that can be sent between processes over RPC. As opposed to , it omits the and document version, making for a smaller serializable representation. This type should be used in RPC contracts that contain lots of range equivalents that need to reduce their payload size for performance. These RPC contracts will need to pass the document and version for the range to be rehydrated into by .

: A serializable representation of , similar to . As opposed to , the document position is saved as two integers ( and ) instead of four (, , and ). This type omits the and document version also and should be used in RPC contracts that contain lots of range equivalents that need to reduce their payload size for performance. These RPC contracts will need to pass the document and version for the range to be rehydrated into by .

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Extensibility.Editor.TextRangeTrackingMode
member.summary: Represents tracking modes for objects.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Extensibility.Editor.TextRangeTrackingMode.EdgeExclusive
member.summary: The leading edge of the range is positive tracking (insertions push the current position towards the end) and the trailing edge is negative tracking (insertions push the current position towards the start). The range will not expand when text changes occur at the range boundaries. For example, if an EdgeExclusive range has Start position 3, and a single character is inserted at position 3, the range will then have Start position 4 and its length will be unchanged.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Extensibility.Editor.TextRangeTrackingMode.EdgeInclusive
member.summary: The leading edge of the range is negative tracking (insertions push the current position toward the start) and the trailing edge is positive tracking (insertions push the current position toward the end). The range will expand when text changes occur at the range boundaries. For example, if an EdgeInclusive range has Start position 3, and a single character is inserted at position 3, the range will then have Start position 3 and its length will be increased by one.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Extensibility.Editor.TextRangeTrackingMode.EdgePositive
member.summary: Both edges of the range are positive tracking (insertions push the current position toward the end).

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Extensibility.Editor.TextRangeTrackingMode.EdgeNegative
member.summary: Both edges of the range are negative tracking (insertions push the current position toward the start).

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Extensibility.Editor.TextRangeTrackingMode.Custom
member.summary: Custom client-determined tracking behavior.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.RpcContracts.Editor.CodeLensTagContract.DisplayBeforeCreatingDataPoints
member.summary: Defines whether this tag should be displayed before creating data points.

remarks.para: true indicates that the tag should be visualized as soon as possible, before evaluating data points. This value should be used when it's guaranteed that there always be at least one data point for this tag (otherwise it might be visualized as an empty space).

false indicates that the tag should not be visualized until at least one data point is created for this tag. This value should be used when it's not guaranteed that there will always be at least one data point for this tag. The tag may be visualized later, but will never be visualized empty.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.RpcContracts.Editor.OffsetRange
member.summary: RPC contract for a text range expressed as offset from the beginning of the document and length.

remarks.para: is one of four closely related concepts:

list.item: : Thick object representing a range of text in a . This type should be used in all code within the same process.
: A serializable representation of that can be sent between processes over RPC. This type should be used in most RPC contracts between processes.

: A serializable representation of that can be sent between processes over RPC. As opposed to , it omits the and document version, making for a smaller serializable representation. This type should be used in RPC contracts that contain lots of range equivalents that need to reduce their payload size for performance. These RPC contracts will need to pass the document and version for the range to be rehydrated into by .

: A serializable representation of , similar to . As opposed to , the document position is saved as two integers ( and ) instead of four (, , and ). This type omits the and document version also and should be used in RPC contracts that contain lots of range equivalents that need to reduce their payload size for performance. These RPC contracts will need to pass the document and version for the range to be rehydrated into by .

member.summary: A struct describing a explicitly versioned range of text in a document.

remarks.para: is one of four closely related concepts:

list.item: : Thick object representing a range of text in a . This type should be used in all code within the same process.
: A serializable representation of that can be sent between processes over RPC. This type should be used in most RPC contracts between processes.

: A serializable representation of that can be sent between processes over RPC. As opposed to , it omits the and document version, making for a smaller serializable representation. This type should be used in RPC contracts that contain lots of range equivalents that need to reduce their payload size for performance. These RPC contracts will need to pass the document and version for the range to be rehydrated into by .

: A serializable representation of , similar to . As opposed to , the document position is saved as two integers ( and ) instead of four (, , and ). This type omits the and document version also and should be used in RPC contracts that contain lots of range equivalents that need to reduce their payload size for performance. These RPC contracts will need to pass the document and version for the range to be rehydrated into by .

member.name: T:Roslyn.Utilities.PerformanceSensitiveAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that a code element is performance sensitive under a known scenario.

remarks.para: When applying this attribute, only explicitly set the values for properties specifically indicated by the test/measurement technique described in the associated .

member.name: P:Roslyn.Utilities.PerformanceSensitiveAttribute.Uri
member.summary: Gets the location where the original problem is documented, likely with steps to reproduce the issue and/or validate performance related to a change in the method.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Utilities.PerformanceSensitiveAttribute.Constraint
member.summary: Gets or sets a description of the constraint imposed by the original performance issue.

remarks.para: Constraints are normally specified by other specific properties that allow automated validation of the constraint. This property supports documenting constraints which cannot be described in terms of other constraint properties.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Utilities.PerformanceSensitiveAttribute.AllowCaptures
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether captures are allowed.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Utilities.PerformanceSensitiveAttribute.AllowImplicitBoxing
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether implicit boxing of value types is allowed.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Utilities.PerformanceSensitiveAttribute.AllowGenericEnumeration
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether enumeration of a generic is allowed.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Utilities.PerformanceSensitiveAttribute.AllowLocks
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether locks are allowed.

member.name: P:Roslyn.Utilities.PerformanceSensitiveAttribute.OftenCompletesSynchronously
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the asynchronous state machine typically completes synchronously.

remarks.para: When , validation of this performance constraint typically involves analyzing the method to ensure synchronous completion of the state machine does not require the allocation of a , either through caching the result or by using .

member.name: P:Roslyn.Utilities.PerformanceSensitiveAttribute.IsParallelEntry
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether this is an entry point to a parallel algorithm.

remarks.para: Parallelization APIs and algorithms, e.g. Parallel.ForEach, may be efficient for parallel entry points (few direct calls but large amounts of iterative work), but are problematic when called inside the iterations themselves. Performance-sensitive code should avoid the use of heavy parallelization APIs except for known entry points to the parallel portion of code.
